bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, February 5, 1901

div1.p: Reed describes the triumph of the Yellow Fever Commission's work, and a Congressional resolution of appreciation.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, February 5, 1901
div1.opener:
Leave Satur-
day 9th on
Ward Lines,
“Havana”-
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Feb. 5th 1901 -
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
I really
think that that long delayed
“function” must have asserted
itself once more, as your
darling letter of January
31st which got here, yesterday
was so much brighter and
so much more like my sweet
oomsey than some of those
other epistles! So you have
really marked January off
the list? Well, so Did I, sweet-
heart, and it makes me very
happy to think that if all
goes well and the ship isn't
delayed by storms, I ought to
be drawing very near to Wash-
ington by this time next week, (9.30 P.M)
Tuesday Evening - My state-
room is all engaged and I
have nothing to do but pack
my trunk, say good-bye to
a few kind people and I am
off for wife and baby bun-
ting- To-day, the paper was
read and met with a most
favorable reception- The
attention during the reading
was all that I could have
asked for & the applause
at its conclusion long
and hearty. A resolution
expressive of the high appre-
ciation in which our work
was held, together with
the thanks of the Congress,
was unanimously adopted.
I received dozens of the
warmest Kinds of hand-
shakes from Cuban, spanish,
Mexican, south-american
& north-american physicians- hands-
shakes men whom I had
not even met- The hall
was crowded & even the
doors packed with listen-
ers- It was indeed
a signal triumph for our
work- But, sweetheart,
I don't care for that
and I am not going to
forget “when the boat sails,”
for I care more for what
my sweet wifie & daughter
carethink and say, than for the
applause of all of the rest
of the world! Do you hear
that, Miss Go-outy? Of course,
you have had snow, and of
Course, the winter will get
in! but just let her “rip”;
I don't care two straws for
all the cold weather you
can get together between
“Cuby” & the North Pole! I've
got too much fat on my ribs now-
to bother about weather! Now,
sweet oomsey, this will prob-
ably be the last letter before
I leave this Sunny Island,
as I'll get home almost as
soon as it does- So, “here's to
you” and to Miss Anna-Polis-
Take care of your darling
selves and meet me with a smile-
Love & kisses & kisses & love for my
precious girls-
